titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ulrich Bonnell Phillips Papers
titlestmt.author: compiled by William E. Brown, Jr. and Kirstin Kay

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday April 18, 2019 at 07:28

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The papers consist of the research files of Ulrich Bonnell Phillips, an author and history professor. The papers include Phillips's notes and transcripts of historical source materials and the collected papers of several southern families from 1712-1933. The collected papers include correspondence, account books, business records, farm and plantation records, diaries, photographs, and other papers which focus primarily on the years 1790-1865, and the Shenandoah Valley region of Virginia and the Piedmont region of Georgia. Phillips's own papers in the collection include a small amount of correspondence, lecture notes, typescript versions of published essays and reviews, transcripts of materials from various sources, his research notes arranged by topic, and related printed matter.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Access is to glass slides and negatives is restricted for preservation purposes. Researchers must use digital surrogates available in the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Unpublished materials authored or otherwise produced by the creator(s) of this collection are in the public domain. There are no restrictions on use. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: All of the glass slides and negatives and many of the other photographic images have been digitally reproduced and are available through the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).
Additional information not yet available in the online version of the finding aid exists in the repository. Contact Manuscripts and Archives for assistance.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Ulrich Bonnell Phillips Papers (MS 397). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Original nitrate negatives were removed from the collection and destroyed following digitization.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The majority of the material was purchased from the estate of U. B. Phillips in 1934. There was also a gift of additional material by Mrs. Phillips and David M. Potter in 1961. Transfer from the Peabody Museum of Natural History, Yale University, 2006.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged in eighteen series and one addition: I. Correspondence, 1748-1961. II. Records, Bonds, and Accounts, 1753-1882. III. Account Books and Diaries, 1812-1899. IV. Pamphlets, 1712-1918. V. Bryan Family, 1828-1883. VI. Cabell-Hare Family, 1792-1825. VII. Dorman Family, 1821-1881. VIII. McDowell Family, 1792-1861. IX. Moore Family, 1794-1865. X. Newton-Steele Family, 1803-1864. XI. Reid Family, 1758-1867. XII. Thomas Family, 1849-1888. XIII. Willson Family, 1806-1869. XIV. Walker Family, 1818-1847. XV. Transcripts. XVI. Manuscripts, 1904-1939. XVII. Research Notes. XVIII. Miscellanea.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The papers consist of the research files of Ulrich Bonnell Phillips, an author and history professor. The papers include Phillips's notes and transcripts of historical source materials and the collected papers of several southern families from 1712-1933. The collected papers include correspondence, account books, business records, farm and plantation records, diaries, photographs, and other papers which focus primarily on the years 1790-1865, and the Shenandoah Valley region of Virginia and the Piedmont region of Georgia. Phillips's own papers in the collection include a small amount of correspondence, lecture notes, typescript versions of published essays and reviews, transcripts of materials from various sources, his research notes arranged by topic, and related printed matter.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Ulrich Bonnell Phillips was born in La Grange, Louisiana, on November 4, 1887. He taught history at several universities, including Yale University (1929-1934). He specialized in southern history, collected primary source material, and published extensively on the subject. Phillips died in New Haven, Connecticut, on January 21, 1934.

bibliography.head: Publication Note
bibliography.p: Reproductions of photographs from Accession 2007-M-012 were published in
bibliography.bibref: Bixel, Patricia Bellis, and John David Smith. Seeing the New South: Race and Place in the Photographs of Ulrich BonnellPhillips. Columbia, SC: University of South Carolina Press, 2013.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains the letters of several individuals and families including: Thomas and Lizzie Armentrout, merchant-farmers in Virginia (bulk dates 1865-92); the Douglass family of Virginia and Missouri (1808-49); Henry St. George Harris, a planter from Virginia (1846-66); and William Letcher Mitchell, chief engineer of the Western and Atlantic Railroad in Georgia (1830-82). Letters to and from several other individuals who lived in the southern United States in the nineteenth century are also included in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of promissory notes, bonds of indebtedness, court records, and accounting volumes. Material of George Rochfort, a merchant from Athens, Georgia (1795-1817) and John Robinson, a whiskey and cloth merchant from Lexington, Virginia (1805-1826) are included in this series. Other items also arranged here include a diary (1857-58) of Richard M. Venable of Virginia, and business and household accounts of Jesse Scott (1821-36), Richard V. Tiffey (1835-37), Thomas Massie (1748-98), Howell and Mary Ann Lamar Cobb (1840-42), and William Letcher Mitchell (1823-29).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains diaries of William and Sarah Mitchell (1823-30) and account books of Mary Ann and Howell Cobb (1840-42), among others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order by type of item.

did.unittitle: Diary (correspondence) of William and Sarah Mitchell
Diary pages of Ulrich Bonnell Phillips

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The two diary pages describe a visit to Paris, August 18-19, and the itinerary for a trip to Europe in July and August.

did.unittitle: Richard V. Tiffey: Daybook of King George Court House
Account Books and Diary general store, farm and cash accounts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a group of published items which focuses on political issues in the southern United States (ca1850-65). Published speeches and addresses by major political figures are included, and certain items are photostatic copies of original documents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The pamphlets and a small quantity of clippings in this series are arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of contracts, correspondence, business papers, and other material relating to Matthew Bryan's iron works operation in Virginia and to his sons' college years at Washington College and the University of Virginia.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of account books, correspondence, and papers documenting the lives of William B. Hare (1760-1818), a physician and landowner, and his descendants. These papers contain information on the economic, social, and political activity in the tidewater region of Virginia, and documentation on tobacco and wheat farming, plantation life, medical practice, slavery, and local merchants. A diary of Philip Rootes (1792 Nov-Dec) is also included in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains correspondence and papers of James Baldwin Dorman (1823-1893), a lawyer, Virginia state legislator, and member of the 1861 Secession Convention. Photostatic copies of papers of James Dorman Davidson, which Phillips obtained from the McCormick Agricultural Library in Chicago, Illinois are also included in this series. Dorman correspondence during the 1840s, and his diary (1841-49) detail his student life at Washington College, and his experiences as a school teacher, traveller, and soldier during the Mexican War. Letters from Dorman's parents, Charles P. and Amanda Elizabeth McCue Dorman, detail family matters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence and papers documenting the lives of family members in Virginia, Kentucky, Missouri, and elsewhere. Family members represented in this series include: James McDowell (1770-1835), a farmer with extensive land holdings in Virginia and Kentucky, a prominent figure in the state militia during the War of 1812, and the father-in-law of Thomas Hart Benton, the Missouri senator whose four letters refer to political topics; James McDowell (1795-1851), a student at Yale College who left a two thousand acre plantation in Kentucky given to him by his father in order to enter Virginia politics as a Democrat. Few political papers detail his activity as a state legislator (1830-38), governor (1843-46), and Congressman (1846-51). Other family members represented to lesser degrees in this series include: James McDowell, a Kentucky physician, and Samuel McDowell and his descendents.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence and papers of Andrew Moore (1752-1821), a representative (1789-99) and senator (1800-09) from Virginia, and Samuel McDowell Moore (1796-1876), a lawyer educated at Washington College who served in the Virginia General Assembly (1825-47), and as a congressman (1833-35). He also campaigned unsuccessfully for governor, and attended the Constitutional Convention of 1829-1830 and the Secession Convention of 1861. Andrew Moore's letters comment on the Embargo and Non-intercourse incidents during the years 1807-1812. Samuel McDowell Moore's letters include references to political and family matters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the papers of John Newton and Robert Steele, brothers-in-law and tradesmen in Virginia. Newton was a hatter, farmer, and justice of the peace, and his papers include several items relating to his official duties as magistrate. Steele was a dry goods merchant whose financial difficulties led him to emigrate to Missouri. His death in the 1840s and the subsequent plight of his family is detailed in letters written by Steele's widow to Newton.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged in chronological order.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, account books, land and legal records, and related papers of several family members in Virginia. Andrew Reid (1751-1837) was a farmer, clerk of the county court, and clerk of the circuit court. His papers include court records, bonds, official documents, and extensive correspondence relating to agricultural matters. Another Andrew Reid (fl. 1805-11) appears as a correspondent in 1805 and, in letters dating through 1811, Reid discusses experiences as a Virginia legislator and as a young lawyer. His extensive correspondence with Samuel McDowell Reid and former Washington College classmates includes mention of family and political affairs, such as the Burr Conspiracy. Samuel McDowell Reid, who succeeded his father Andrew as clerk of the county and superior courts also served in the Virginia legislature during the Civil War, ran a large legal practice, supervised four major estates, managed family lands in the west, and served as a trustee for Washington College. Correspondence documents his activity as a lawyer, businessman, legislator, and plantation manager. Reid frequently dealt with the issue of slavery in his business dealings, and it is a common topic in his letters.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in two sections: Financial accounts and Correspondence. Financial accounts files are arranged alphabetically and Correspondence files are arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of the correspondence and papers of Thomas W. Thomas, a lawyer in Elberton, Georgia, and active in Democratic politics until 1850, when he joined with Howell Cobb, Robert Toombs, and Alexander H. Stephens to form the Constitutional Union Party of Georgia. He later became a judge in the state superior court and a colonel in the Confederate army. Correspondence details Thomas's legal and financial affairs, and includes letters from many minor Georgia political figures and other family members.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, financial records, and papers relating to the land holdings and farming activities of Thomas Willson, a Virginia and Indiana farmer. Correspondence with his Indiana agents: Thomas McClure, Arthur Compton, and John Buntain document more than thirty years of agricultural activity. Willson's letters with his brother William B., an Ohio physician, also focus on farming matters.

The remaining papers document the lives of the children and grandchildren of James S. Willson, a brother of Thomas and William B. Willson. Elizabeth Ann Willson, an unmarried daughter, and two sons, William Finley Willson, another Ohio physician, and Thomas Newton Willson, a schoolteacher, discuss abolitionist views, pro-slavery sentiments, and family, economic, and political matters with each other and their father James.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence among members of the Walker family in Virginia and relatives in the South and West. Joseph and John B. Walker comment on Missouri land speculations, Hugh and James C. Walker detail life in Tennessee, William and Sam Walker detail life at Princeton, and Henry Brown writes of his preaching experiences in the Kanawha Valley.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series contains material arranged chronologically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Ulrich B. Phillips' research notes relating to southern history. Phillips transcribed historical sources in academic institutions, libraries, and private sources. Selected portions of these transcripts appeared in such published works as The Correspondence of Robert Toombs, Alexander H. Stephens, and Howell Cobb. Most of the material in this series is undated; specific dates are noted at the file level below only when known.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in four sections: General, Plantations, Politics, and Transportation. Each section is arranged alphabetically by topic.

did.unittitle: Economics of slavery in the South
Fortunes (of the Confederate people) in war
Non-agricultural pursuits of slaves and freedmen
Slavery, plantation, etc., in the tropics
Southern Industrial Society: transcripts, notes, outline for Plantation and Frontier
Rules for the management and medical treatment of slaves
Massie Mss, description of, Univ. of Texas
South Carolina, The Charleston Morning Post

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains drafts of published and unpublished writings by Phillips and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in two sections: Phillips, Ulrich Bonnell, and Others. Each section is arranged in chronological order.

unittitle.title: True History of the Civil War

did.unittitle: Origin and Growth of Black Belts

unittitle.title: The South in the Building of the Nation
Plantations with Slave Labor and Free
The Central Theme of Southern History
The Historic Defense of Negro Slavery

did.unittitle: Reviews: Carpenter, Johnson, Twelve Southerners, Odum, and Mitchell

unittitle.title: Plantations East and South of Suez

did.unittitle: Reviews: W.J. de Renne Catalogue, Abernathy

unittitle.title: The South in the Building of the Nation
Traits and Contributions of F. J. Turner

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains Phillips's unorganized three by five inch research note cards on subjects relating to U.S. and Southern history. Note cards in this series are undated.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains a box of lantern slides relating to Southern history, clippings of newspaper and journal articles reflecting the work of Phillips, photographs complimenting Phillips's writings on Southern history, and printed ephemera and manuscripts unrelated to materials in other series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by record type: Lantern slides, Clippings, Photographs, Other material.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Alternate Formats: All of these images have been digitally reproduced in the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the original glass negatives and slides is restricted. Researchers must use digital images in MADID.

did.unittitle: Campaign flag for Henry Clay and Theodore Frelinghuysen

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the Peabody Museum of Natural History, Yale University, 2006.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This accession contains photographs, glass negatives, stereoscopic photographs, and a small amount of printed ephemera documenting the southeastern United States, especially South Carolina and Louisiana, during the first part of the twentieth century. Subjects depicted included blacks, both casually and at work; city and rural life; and work activity in cotton and sugar cane fields. Photographs also document buildings, including cabins, slave quarters, plantation homes, farms, and cities. Most of the photographs are undated and are circa 1900-circa 1930 unless more specific dates are noted at the file level below. Some of the photographs are annotated with plate numbers and appear to have been used as illustrations in Phillips's books.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This accession is arranged by type of material; photographs are arranged alphabetically by topic.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Alternate Formats: Some of the photographic materials in this accession have been digitally reproduced in the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processing Information: During the processing of this accession, the approximately 100 nitrate negatives were compared against the photographic prints in the collection and approximately half of the nitrate negatives were identified as duplicates and removed from the collection. The remaining unique nitrate negatives were digitized and then removed from the collection.

did.unittitle: Photographic reproductions of engravings depicting plantation life
H. C. Hall photographs of the South

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of The Oaks, a plantation near the Cooper River in South Carolina.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an offprint of Wiley, B. I., "Vicissitudes of Early Reconstruction Farming in the Lower Mississippi Valley," Journal of Southern History 3:4 (1937 Nov).

did.unittitle: Stereoscopic photographs of New Orleans by S. T. Blessing

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Alternate Format: Twelve of these negatives have been digitally reproduced in the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).

did.unittitle: Glass negatives and slides of the south

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These negatives and slides represent twenty-eight different images (two are duplicates). Eleven of the glass slides in this box duplicate lantern slides in Series XVIII, box 45.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Alternate Format: All of these images have been digitally reproduced in the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID).

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Access to the original glass negatives and slides is restricted. Researchers must use digital images in MADID.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes images of people, black and white; rural scenes; plantations; city buildings; and interiors.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Alternate Format: All of these images have been digitally reproduced in the Manuscripts and Archives Digital Image Database (MADID). Search for "nitrate negatives" to retrieve them.

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Materials
separatedmaterial.p: Original nitrate negatives were removed from the collection and destroyed following digitization.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Contact Public Services (phone: 203 432-1735, e-mail: mssa.reference@yale.edu) for information regarding access to the TIFF image files.
